title: Verified Purchase
content: “First lie wins,” says the narrator of Ashley Elston's episodic thriller that looks into the grifting life of Evie, as she is first called, who tells us she’s on assignment to go to a small town in Louisiana near the Texas border. Apparently she is supposed to ruin the life of Ryan who, apparently smitten, invites her to move in with him at the house he’s inherited from his grandfather. Can she trust him?
post_time: Reviewed in the United States on April 10, 2024

title: "I guess I wasn't the only one looking for a connection with someone else

post_time: Reviewed in the United States on August 28, 2024

title: Verified Purchase
content: Soon enough we find out who she really is, and the rest of the book alternates between the book’s present, and Evie's narration of the various cases she’s handled (all under different names) for a certain Mr. Smith, who she knows only from written messages and phone calls from a voice-distorting phone. The unifier is that she messed up in her last assignment, and the mysterious “Mr. Smith” is giving her one more chance.
post_time: Reviewed in the United States on August 9, 2024

title: Good mystery
content: But Evie, as you shall see, is not without resources of her own. And when she sees that she is being set up to again fail on this last-chance mission she . . . ah, but that would be telling.
post_time: Reviewed in the United States on September 18, 2024

title: Verified Purchase
content: The story is narrated in the first person by Evie in sort of a stream of consciousness style, which is not only perfect conceptually for the tale but also allows you to spot clues that Evie, at the time she relates the incidents, does not yet know are clues. (Or does she?) So pay attention. For example, in one instance she completes the assignment, and after she does she unexpectedly learns something else about the case. “Interesting,” she says.
post_time: Reviewed in the United States on September 18, 2024

title: Fun and Entertaining!
content: Notes and asides. Minor sex. Minimal violence. The book really cries out for a screenplay treatment, and Kristen Stewart should be offered the part of Evie. There’s a scene in the book that’s virtually an homage to Hitchcock. You’ll spot it if you’ve seen “Marnie.”

title: Verified Purchase
content: Lucca Marino  was always resilient. She had to be. When in her teen years, caring for a dying mother with never enough money for medication - whats a girl going to do? With that question, she begins her life of crime. But someone has an eye on her and soon she is caught up in a cat and mouse con game with a  handler, Mr. Smith, who controls her next job, next mark, and her next identity.  Smart, creative, and always trying to stay a step ahead, Lucca aka Izzy or Mia or Evie does her best to complete the job she is assigned. This  book is filled with twists and turns, suspenseful situations, and hold-your-breath action that never stops. I found myself rooting for Lucca no matter who she was or what her job entailed. She is a wonderful character! Smart, creative, dangerous, and desperately wanting  the dream she shared with her mother - a little house with a white picket fence, and a garden. But, Mr Smith is in control of her…one might say, he owns her. And, Mr. Smith plays dirty. A solid four star rating for this highly entertaining novel.
post_time: Reviewed in the United States on August 2, 2024

title: Verified Purchase

I did have a hard time with the back and forth between present day and past years as well as Evie/Lucca’s jobs she had. I had to go back and remember who certain people were. I’m still a little unclear of the end….is she now the new “Smith” meaning she will continue this line of work as the head honcho or what. All in all, I couldn’t stop reading the book and it kept me interested and intrigued!
